Package net.proteusframework.ui.workspace

The workspace API provides a framework for managing UIs based on tasks and events.

Package net.proteusframework.ui.workspace Description

The workspace API provides a framework for managing UIs based on tasks and events. The primary goal of this API is to decouple UI interactions allowing independent reusable UIs to be created by providing a communication mechanism for tasks, UIs, and a task manager. The arbiter for this communication is the Workspace.

Workspace exposes an event-handler API for communication between UIs and the workspace framework. The event-handler API facilitates decoupling a UI need from the UI implementation. For example, a user may click a button to edit a database record in a listing UI. The UI need in this case is to edit the database record. There could be many different implementations of an editor for that type of database record. The implementation chosen could vary for any number of business reasons such as the type of user that clicked the button. Instead of coding the business logic for selecting the database record editor UI into the listing UI, the listing UI can instead request that someone else make the decision of which UI to show. The listing UI just makes a request that a UI be shown to edit the database record. Some other code will be responsible for making the decision of which editor UI will be used and how it will be configured. This is done by having the listing UI send an edit event for the database record. The workspace framework is responsible for routing that event to a handler that can respond to it. Now, the logic for which editor to open for the database record and how it will be configured can be encapsulated in a handler specifically written for the business needs of the application. Essentially, the workspace API allows us to wire together UIs and plugin alternate behavior as-needed without rewriting the entire application. The same event-handler API is used to notify other UIs of changes that may affect them. The listing UI is a common example of this. When the user finishes saves changes to the database record the editor UI can send an event indicating that a change occurred. The listing UI would handle these events by making sure the UI was updated to show any changes.

It is possible to add a UITask directly to a workspace bypassing the event-handler method previously described. If this approach is taken, then we are tightly coupling different UIs together removing the ability to reuse them independently. This is commonly done for projects where we are creating UIs that cannot be reused elsewhere and the business logic is simple to include within the UI code.

Workspaces can persist and restore the state of the tasks that are in the Workspace at any time. This feature allows an application to save the current state of the workspace so a user can pick up where they left off later. For example, in the CMS back-end, we use this feature to save the state of the workspace when a user switches Sites or logs out of the system. The state is restored when the workspace UI is shown again. This feature is limited to UITasks that indicate that they support serialization. Since we currently use Java serialization for this feature, it isn't supported for scripted UITasks.
